metadata.title: A new isolation method for rat intraepithelial lymphocytes

abstract.text: . Intraepithelial lymphocytes IELs play critical roles in gut immunity. In mice, gd T cells are a large component of the IEL population. In the rat, gd IELs are reportedly much less common, but technical issues suggest that previous analyses should be interpreted cautiously. The study of IELs in rats has been impeded by isolation procedures that are lengthy and complex, leading to small cell yields. For this reason, it is possible that rat IELs analyzed in previous studies have not been representative of the entire IEL compartment. We report a new method for the isolation of rat IELs that is based on the selective removal of intestinal epithelial cells under conditions that leave the basement membrane undisturbed. The method is rapid and requires neither enzymatic digestion, nor surgical removal of Peyer's patches, nor vigorous mechanical manipulation of the intestine. The yield of rat IELs using this method is 5-to 10-fold greater than that reported for other methods. Morphological and phenotypic analyses demonstrated that the purified cell population is comprised of IELs and is not contaminated with lamina propria or Peyer's patch lymphocytes. Phenotypic analysis revealed five major subsets of IELs Ž . y based on differential cell surface expression of CD4, CD8, and ab T cell receptor TcR . Among the abTcR cells was a population of gd T cells present at levels not previously detected. The isolation of IEL sub-populations using this methodology should facilitate studies of the function of these cells in gut immunity. q 1999 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.
0022-1759r99r$ -see front matter q 1999 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. Ž . PII: S 0 0 2 2 -1 7 5 9 9 9 0 0 0 1 5 -0 ( ) D. Todd et al.

body_text.text: Intestinal lymphoid cells are present in three physically and functionally distinct tissue compartments:

AbbreÕiations: TcR, T cell receptor; DTE, dithioerythritol; IEL, intraepithelial lymphocyte; H&E, hematoxylin and eosin; NK, natural killer; PE, phycoerythrin; FITC, fluorescein isothiocyanate; WF, Wistar Furth ) Corresponding author. Division of Diabetes, Biotech 2, Suite 218, 373 Plantation Street, Worcester, MA 01605, USA. Tel.: q 1-508-856-3800; Fax: q 1-508-856-4093; E-m ail: rita.bortell@umassmed.edu the lamina propria, Peyer's patches, and the intraep-Ž . ithelial space Lefrançois, 1994 . Analyses of cell populations in each of these compartments has been impeded by isolation methods that yield small numbers of cells and do not reproducibly prevent cross-Ž contamination Davies and Parrott, 1981; Mosley and Klein, 1992; Lefrançois, 1994; Ebert and Roberts, 1995; Kearsey and Stadnyk, 1996; Teitelbaum et al., . 1996a,b . This has been particularly true for analyses Ž . of rat intraepithelial lymphocytes IELs , only 5-10 million of which have typically been isolated from one animal. Different laboratories have reported variable cell Ž yields and IEL phenotypes Fangmann et al., 1991a; Takimoto et al., 1992; Torres-Nagel et al., 1992; Kuhnlein et al., 1994; Gorczynski et al., 1996; Kearsey and Stadnyk, 1996; Helgeland et al., 1997;  . Kearsey and Stadnyk, 1997 . Nonetheless, based on available purification methods, a working consensus has been reached on the phenotype of rat IELs ŽTakimoto et al., 1992; Sakai et al., 1994; Helgeland et al., 1996; Kearsey and Stadnyk, 1996; Teitelbaum et al., 1996a,b; Waite et al., 1996; . q Ž 1997 . The majority appear to be CD8 Sakai et al., . q 1994; Teitelbaum et al., 1996a,b . Many of the CD8 Ž IELs express the CD8ara homodimer Torres-Nagel . Ž . et al., 1992 . The majority of rat IELs ) 95% also express the RT6 surface differentiation alloantigen at Ž high density Fangmann et al., 1990; Fangmann et al., 1991a,b; Colle et al., 1992; Fangmann et al., . 1993; Waite et al., 1996 . Most investigators have reported that ) 90% of IELs in euthymic rats ex-Ž . press the ab T cell receptor TcR whereas -10% Ž express the gdTcR Fangmann et al., 1991b; Torres-Nagel et al., 1992; Kuhnlein et al., 1994; Kearsey and Stadnyk, 1996; Waite et al., 1996;  . Helgeland et al., 1997 . The original protocols developed for IEL isolation require dissection to remove Peyer's patches, and mincing of the tissue to physically disrupt the epithe-Ž lium Davies and Parrott, 1981; Lundqvist et al., . 1992 ; Mosley and Klein, 1992; Lefrançois, 1994 . This method is limited by variable, sometimes extensive, contamination of the IEL preparation with lamina propria lymphocytes. To address this problem, Ž the original protocols for IEL isolation Davies and . Parrott, 1981; Lefrançois, 1994 have required enzymatic digestion, chelation with agents like EDTA, Ž panning, andror magnetic bead separation Davies and Parrott, 1981; Lundqvist et al., 1992; Mosley . and Klein, 1992; Lefrançois, 1994 . None of the modifications have proven entirely satisfactory.

An alternative method for IEL isolation everts, ligates, and distends the intestine, which is then Ž . incubated with dithioerythritol DTE and subjected Ž to repeated rigorous vortexing Mayrhofer and . Whately, 1983 . Using discontinuous Percoll gradient centrifugation, yields of ; 5 = 10 6 IELsrrat Ž that are ; 90% pure have been obtained Kearsey . and Stadnyk, 1996 . Contamination of this IEL preparation with lymphocytes from lamina propria and Peyer's patches is minimal. The low cell yield, however, makes it uncertain that phenotypic and functional characteristics of IELs prepared in this way are representative of the entire, much larger, Ž IEL compartment Mayrhofer and Whately, 1983;  . Kearsey and Stadnyk, 1996 . To address these issues, we have developed an efficient new technique for the rapid isolation of large numbers of highly purified rat IELs. The technique is based in part on the susceptibility of intestinal epithelial cells to hypoxic conditions that leave the basement membrane relatively undisturbed. The sloughed epithelium carries with it the IELs, effectively dissecting away the lamina propria and Peyer's patches. IELs prepared in this way are high in yield and purity. They contain five major subsets, including a population of gd T cells present at levels much higher than previously described.

Single-, two-, and three-color flow cytometric analyses were performed as previously described Ž . Zadeh et al., 1996; Iwakoshi et al., 1998 . Briefly, 1 = 10 6 viable lymph node cells or IELs were reacted with a mixture of fluorescein isothiocyanate Ž . Ž . FITC , biotin, andror phycoerythrin PE -conjugated mAbs for 20 min at 48C. All IEL analyses were performed after nylon wool or Percoll-density gradient purification to remove the large number of contaminating dead epithelial cells. Cells were then washed, reacted with Cy-Chrome w -conjugated Ž . streptavidin PharMingen to visualize biotinylated mAbs, washed again, and fixed with 1% paraformaldehyde. FITC-, biotin-and PE-conjugated isotype Ž . control immunoglobulins PharMingen were used for all analyses. Cells were analyzed using a FACSw Ž . can instrument Becton Dickinson, Sunnyvale, CA . Lymphoid cells were identified by their forward and side light-scatter profiles and the detection of RT6, abTcR, or gdTcR staining. The composite phenotypes of lymphoid cell subsets for up to four antigenic markers were determined by combining the results of multiple two-and three-color analyses of replicate samples of lymphocytes, each incubated with a different combination of antibodies.

To characterize the sub-population containing NKR-P1 q cells using three color flow cytometry, we exploited the unique staining patterns of CD8a , CD4, and abTcR on IELs. Because -1% of IELs express the CD8a y CD4 y a bTcR q phenotype, further analysis of CD8a y CD4 y a bTcR y IELs was possible by labeling with CD8a and CD4, selecting the CD8a y CD4 y IEL subset, and performing three color analysis using a third fluorochrome.

To characterize the CD8 q CD4 y a bTcR y subpopulation, we again exploited the unique staining patterns of CD8a , CD4, and abTcR on IELs. Because CD8a q CD4 q a bTcR y IELs comprise -1% of IELs, it was possible to stain for CD8a and abTcR, select the CD8a q abTcR y cells, and examine this population using a third fluorochrome, e.g., anti-gdTcR using the V65 mAb. IELs expressing the CD8a q CD4 y a bTcR y phenotype were shown to be q Ž . gdTcR see Fig. 6 . Sub-populations of cells with this phenotype were therefore identifiable by dual labeling for V65 and a second fluorochrome.

Strategies for analyzing the remaining three abTcR q populations were as follows. Because CD8a y CD4 q a bTcR y cells comprise -1% of total IELs, CD8a y CD4 q a bTcR q IELs could be analyzed by staining for CD8a and CD4, selecting for CD8a y CD4 q cells, and examining this population using a third fluorochrome. Because CD8a q CD4 q abTcR y cells comprise -1% of total IELs, D8a q CD4 q a bTcR q IELs could be analyzed by staining for CD8a and CD4, selecting for CD8a q CD4 q cells, and examining this population using a third fluorochrome. Finally, because CD8a y CD4 y abTcR q cells comprise -1% of total IELs, CD8a q CD4 y a bTcR q IELs could be analyzed by staining for CD4 and abTcR, selecting for CD4 y abTcR q cells, and examining this population using a third fluorochrome.

To prepare IELs, the proximal 3-4 cm of intestine including the duodenum was first dissected free of the pancreas, and the bowel was transected at the level of the pyloric sphincter. The remainder of the small intestine was dissected free of omentum by gentle blunt dissection, transected 1 cm proximal to the ileo-cecal junction, and removed en bloc. Care was taken to avoid perforation of the intestine during dissection. Intestinal contents were removed by gen-Ž . tly flushing the lumen with 50 ml of cold 48C ( ) RPMI 1640 over a 3-min period using a 1-mm gavage tube inserted into the proximal lumen. Flushing to remove fecal material was performed gently, at low pressure, and without squeezing the bowel, so as not to perforate the bowel wall or disturb the epithelial mucus coating that contains large numbers of lymphoid cells. The intestine was then immersed in cold RPMI 1640 and incubated on ice for 60-120 min. IELs were recovered in a two step procedure.

Step 1: After cold incubation, the intestinal lumen Ž . was flushed at low pressure over several minutes with 10 ml of medium consisting of HEPES-buffered HBSS containing 1 mM DTE and 10% Fetalclone w I Ža defined neonatal bovine serum, HyClone, Logan,
. UT at 378C. The lumenal eluate was saved.

Step 2: The weakly adherent epithelial cells and mucus coating remaining in the intestine were then squeezed out by manual compression as follows. The proximal end of the intestine was grasped between thumb and index finger and suspended vertically over a polystyrene container. The thumb and index finger of the other hand were then slid along the entire length of the gut, compressing it from duodenum to distal ileum to extrude mucus and cellular contents. Care was taken to avoid tearing the tissue.

The specimen was subjected to a total of five Ž . Ž . cycles of flushing Step 1 and squeezing Step 2 to extrude all intra-lumenal contents. The contents of all five 10 ml flushes and extrusions were combined in one 50 ml polystyrene test tube. The tube was then gently swirled to suspend all cells. Clumps of material present in the dispersed sediment were allowed to settle for 10 min. The supernatant containing single dispersed epithelial cells and IELs was then removed by pipetting into a second tube and centrifuged at 350 = G for 5 min. The resulting pellet, containing IELs, erythrocytes, and epithelial cells, was then recovered and subjected to either nylon wool or density gradient centrifugation for further purification.

The viability of IELs prepared in this way was assessed immediately after their recovery by the method of Trypan blue exclusion. We observed that ) 95% of the lymphoid cells were viable. In contrast, ) 90% of the epithelial cells in the freshly isolated population failed to exclude the dye.

Cervical and mesenteric lymph nodes were removed and single cell suspensions were prepared by gentle extrusion through stainless steel sieves into Ž . cold medium Zadeh et al., 1996 . Intestine was removed prior to the recovery of mesenteric lymph nodes.

Nylon wool purification of IEL suspensions was Ž performed as described previously Lefrançois, . 1994 . Briefly, pelleted cells were suspended in 10 ml cold RPMI containing 5% Fetalclone w I, and passed through a loosely packed nylon wool column at the rate of 1 drop every 1-2 s. The column was washed with cold medium containing 5% Fetalclone w I. The number of viable cells with lymphoid morphology was quantified using a hemocytometer and the method of Trypan blue exclusion.

A two step discontinuous Percoll density gradient centrifugation procedure was used in some experi-Ž . Todd et al.r Journal of Immunological Methods 224 1999 111-127 115 Ž . ments Kearsey and Stadnyk, 1996 . Briefly, pelleted cells were re-suspended in 35 ml RPMI containing 5% Fetalclone w I at room temperature; 15 ml of Percoll was then added to generate a 30% Percoll solution. The cell suspension was centrifuged at 350 = G for 15 min at room temperature. Non-viable ( ) epithelial cells were excluded from the 30% Percoll solution, whereas erythrocytes, lymphocytes, and viable epithelial cells localized to the pellet. The cell pellet was suspended in 15 ml of a 45% Percoll solution. A second 75% Percoll solution was layered under the 45% solution, and the discontinuous Percoll gradient was then centrifuged at 350 = G for 30 min. Viable epithelial cells were recovered from the supernatant at the 45% interface. Red blood cells and debris migrated into the layer of 75% Percoll. Viable IELs were collected from the interface between the 45% and 75% Percoll layers. The number of viable cells that excluded Trypan blue was quantified using a hemocytometer and was ) 95% in all cases.

body_text.section: Discontinuous Percoll density gradient purification of IELs

body_text.text: Samples of 16-week old WF rat intestine for histological analysis were taken at three different stages of the IEL isolation procedure. The first was obtained immediately after the animal was killed in an atmosphere of 100% CO . The second was recov-2 ered after incubation at 48C, but before perfusion with medium at 378C. The third was recovered after five perfusions and extrusions. Specimens were immediately fixed in 10% buffered formalin or Bouin's fixative. Paraffin-embedded tissue sections of all samples were stained with hematoxylin and eosin Ž .

H & E and examined by light microscopy. Samples of the extruded intra-lumenal contents were embedded in paraffin, stained with H & E, and examined by light microscopy. Cytospin-prepared slides of Percoll-purified IEL were prepared and stained with Giemsa for analysis of purity.

Samples of WF intestine were taken at different stages of the isolation procedure and examined by The total number of viable mononuclear cells present in the purified preparations was determined using a hemocytometer.

The percentage of lymphocytes present in the purified cell populations was measured by flow cytometry on the basis of forwardand side-scatter. The number of individual samples tested is shown in parenthesis except in the case of the percentage of lymphocytes present in Percoll-purified cells. In this instance, the percentage was measured on a single pool of IELs from four animals. Data are expressed as the mean"s.d. light microscopy. Fig. 1 , panel A shows the anatomy of normal 16-week old WF rat jejunum. Panels B, C, and D show progressive changes in gut morphology during processing for the recovery of IELs. They Ž . Ž document delamination panel B and removal pan-. els C and D of the intestinal epithelium from the basement membrane. Panels C and D also document the presence of intact lamina propria and Peyer's patches in the residual processed intestine. Panel E shows the morphology of cells present in the unpurified lumenal washing after five cycles of extrusion. Numerous mononuclear cells are present together with epithelial cells.

body_text.text: IEL yield and purity were measured after nylon wool or Percoll purification of the lumenal washings. Nylon wool purification resulted in higher yields of IELs but slightly lower purity than did Percoll purification.

Flow cytometric analysis revealed that ) 97% of cells were lym-Ž . phocytes Fig. 2, panel B . Analysis of the lightscattering properties of both the nylon wool and Percoll-purified lymphoid cells revealed that they were slightly larger than peripheral lymph node cells Ž . Fig. 2 , panel C . Morphological analyses of Percoll-purified cells revealed large numbers of mononuclear cells similar in appearance to unfrac-Ž . tionated lymph node cells Fig. 1 , panel F . Some of these mononuclear cells are large and appear to contain granules.

The phenotype of purified intestinal lymphocyte populations was determined by flow cytometry. In preliminary studies, it was determined that the phenotypes of the intestinal lymphoid cells purified by nylon wool and by Percoll density gradient centrifu-Ž . gation were qualitatively similar data not shown . The phenotypic analyses presented below were performed on nylon wool-purified cells.

The phenotype of cells isolated using our methodology displayed the consensus phenotype of IELs ŽTakimoto et al., 1992; Sakai et al., 1994; Helgeland et al., 1996; Kearsey and Stadnyk, 1996; Teitelbaum et al., 1996a,b; Waite et al., 1996; . Taken together, these phenotypic and morphological results confirm that our methodology selectively isolates IELs while excluding contaminating lamina propria and Peyer's patch lymphocytes, a large number of which express B220.

body_text.text: . Fig. 5 , middle panel . This phenotype identifies them as NK cells. In addition, we observed that the majority of NKR-P1 q NK IELs express high levels Ž . of cell surface RT6 Fig. 5 , bottom panel . In dual label analyses, we observed that ; 8% of the IELs co-expressed CD3 and NKR-P1, a phenotype that is consistent with that of NK T cells. Additional duallabel analyses using anti-CD8a and anti-CD3 antibodies revealed that -1.5% of the IEL population is CD3 y CD8a q , making it unlikely that the NK IEL population is significantly contaminated with CD8 q peripheral NK cells.

body_text.text: A second surprising observation was that 24.4 " Ž . 3.3% N s 6 of all IELs were labeled by the V65 Ž . anti-gdTcR mAb Fig. 6 , left panel . Because abTcR and gdTcR are not co-expressed on T cells, and because the data above indicate that the great majority of CD8 y CD4 y a bTcR y cells are NK cells, we next tested the hypothesis that the gdTcR q cells would be found in the CD8 q CD4 y abTcR y subpopulation. We observed that 94.9 " 1.5% of the q y q Ž CD8a abTcR population was gdTcR Fig. 6 , . right panel , accounting in turn for 95% of all gdTcR q IELs.

body_text.text: To confirm that this high percentage of gdTcR q IELs was not specific to the WF rat, we also measured the number of CD8 q abTcR y IELs isolated in the same way from rats of five additional strains. The number of CD8 q abTcR y IELs in these strains Ž was 19.0 " 6.3% range 10.0% to 27.8%, N s 9 . samples . This percentage is comparable to that ob-Ž . served in WF rats of the same age Table 2 .

To do so, we again exploited the unique staining patterns of Ž . CD8a , CD4, and abTcR on IELs see Section 2 .
body_text.section: Phenotypic characteristics of the fiÕe major IEL subsets

body_text.text: The expression of CD2, CD3, CD5, CD25, CD28, CD45RC intermediate , and RT6.2 on each of the five major sub-populations of WF IELs is shown in Table  Ž 3. Consistent with previous reports Fangmann et al., . 1991a,b; Waite et al., 1996 , RT6 was expressed uniformly and at high density on four of the five IEL subsets. In contrast, its expression on the CD4 q CD8 y IEL subset was heterogeneous and at low density, a pattern also observed on CD4 q pe-Ž . ripheral T cells Crisa et al., 1990 .
body_text.section: Phenotypic characteristics of the fiÕe major IEL subsets

body_text.text: Ž Consistent with previous reports Fangmann et . al., 1991b , we observed that, unlike peripheral T cells, few IELs expressed CD2. Those cells that were CD2 q were found in the CD4 q CD8 y sub-population. Only one sub-population failed to express CD3; this was the CD4 y CD8 y subset, which also failed to express abTcR or gdTcR and, as documented above, was comprised predominantly of NK cells.
body_text.section: Phenotypic characteristics of the fiÕe major IEL subsets

body_text.text: Most IELs, including gdTcR q IELs, appeared to be in an activated state as evidenced by their uniform expression of CD25. Surprisingly, despite the expression of CD25, many IELs, including those in the gdTcR q subset, did not express CD28. CD28 is a co-stimulatory molecule expressed constitutively on most peripheral T cells and at high levels on activated T cells.

body_text.text: Most subsets of IELs contained low percentages of CD45RC intermediate cells. Only the CD4 y abTcR q subset contained levels of CD45RC intermediate cells Ž

body_text.text: The percentage of CD5 q cells varied among the different IEL subsets. CD5 was expressed by a very low percentage of gdTcR q and CD8 y CD4 y IELs, approximately half of CD4 y abTcR q IELs, and the great majority of CD8a q CD4 q and CD8a y CD4 q IELs.
body_text.section: Phenotypic characteristics of the fiÕe major IEL subsets

body_text.text: The analysis of rat IEL populations recovered using our new isolation procedure has generated three principal findings. First, the method leads to ( ) the recovery of 5-to 10-fold more IELs than are Ž recovered using older methods Fangmann et al., 1991b; Teitelbaum et al., 1995; Kearsey and Stadnyk, 1996; Teitelbaum et al., 1996a,b; Kearsey and . Stadnyk, 1997 . The method is reproducible and yields lymphoid cell preparations that are of high purity and exhibit the consensus morphologic and phenotypic characteristics of true IELs. Second, analysis of rat IELs prepared using the new method revealed the presence of gd T cells at levels not previously appreciated. In general, ; 25% of the cells in each preparation were gdTcR q cells. Third, three-color microfluorometric analysis classified ) 99% of the rat IELs into one of five major sub-populations based on their expression of TcR, CD4 and CD8. Surprisingly, one of these sub-populations was comprised predominantly of NK cells.

The new method that we describe is rapid and reproducibly yields large numbers of viable IELs. The technique is based on the propensity of intestinal epithelial cells to slough off the gut basement membrane after exposure to cold and hypoxic culture conditions that leave the basement membrane relatively undisturbed. The sloughed epithelium carries with it the IEL population, effectively dissecting away the lamina propria and Peyer's patches.

The procedure yields a population of cells that fulfill three criteria that define a successful IEL purification process. First, the lamina propria and Peyer's patches remain intact throughout the isolation procedure. Second, the morphology and lightscattering properties of the recovered cells are those of intestinal epithelial lymphocytes. Finally, the phenotype of the purified cells is consistent with that of Ž an IEL population Fangmann et al., 1990; Kearsey . and Stadnyk, 1996 . The methodology is noteworthy for two additional reasons. The first is its technical simplicity. It requires no special reagents or equipment, nor does it require extensive or vigorous mechanical disturbance of the intestine. It takes only 2-3 h, yet reproducibly generates large numbers of pure IELs.

Second, and more importantly, the methodology appears to generate cell populations that are more representative of the entire IEL compartment than are populations generated by older methods. We believe this to be the case because our method overcomes two obstacles that have previously impeded recovery of pure IELs. First, it dissects away epithelial cells from the intestine without disrupting the basement membrane. This prevents contamination of IEL preparations with lamina propria and Peyer's patch lymphocytes. Second, it eliminates many purification steps that have previously been required. These include incubation in chelating agents, mincing, vigorous shaking, eversion of the Ž . intestine, and panning Lefrançois, 1994 . Each of those procedures can cause substantial non-specific cell losses, leading to low cell yields. Previously published isolation protocols yield 5-15 million Ž IELsrrat Fangmann et al., 1991b; Teitelbaum et al., . 1995; Kearsey and Stadnyk, 1996 . The IEL population in the rat has, however, been estimated to be 10-Ž to 20-fold larger Cerf-Bensussan and Guy-Grand, . 1991; Kraehenbuhl and Neutra, 1992 . The method we have developed routinely yields 30-50 million IELsrrat.

Ž Consistent with previous reports Fangmann et . al., 1991b , many of the IELs isolated with our q q q Ž procedure were CD8 RT6 abTcR Fangmann et al., 1990; Takimoto et al., 1992; Torres-Nagel et al., . 1992; Kearsey and Stadnyk, 1997 . Few were CD4 q CD8 q or CD8 y CD4 q . A major new finding, however, was the identification of a population of gdTcR q IELs that comprise ; 25% of total IELs recovered. Previously it has been reported that V65stained gdTcR q IELs comprise either -10% ŽKuhnlein et al., 1994; Helgeland et al., 1997;  . Ž Kearsey and Stadnyk, 1997 or 10- 20% Helgeland . et al., 1996; Gorczynski et al., 1996 of the rat IEL population. The percentage of gdTcR q cells has been reported to be 40-50% of the total IEL popula-Ž . tion in the mouse Goodman and Lefrançois, 1988 , and the present data suggest that the rat IEL population may be more like that of the mouse than previously thought.
It could be argued that the high percentage of gdTcR q IELs we observed reflects a selective loss of abTcR q IELs due to hypoxic isolation conditions, but we think such an explanation is unlikely.

( ) First, the absolute number of abTcR q cells that we recovered was higher than that produced by other methods. In addition, analysis of lymphoid cells immediately after the flushing step in our procedure revealed ) 90% viability.

We recognize, however, that a number of factors other than isolation methodology could influence gdTcR q IEL percentages. For example, there could be compartmentalization of gdTcR q cells in the gut, and the percentage of these cells could vary along its length. Our procedure isolated IELs from the entire small bowel, and it is possible that previous reports based on the older methodology simply used different regions of the bowel. In a preliminary study, however, we found high percentages of gdTcR q IELs in proximal, middle, and distal small intestine Ž . DT, unpublished observations . It could also be argued that the proportion of gdTcR q cells in the WF rat IEL compartment may differ from the proportion in rats of other strains or ages. Our analysis of five phenotypically normal strains at ; 10 weeks of age suggests that, although there is some strain-to-strain variability, the percentage in WF rats is not uniquely high. Whether the percentage is also high in older or younger animals analyzed by our method is not yet established, however.

Our three-color microfluorometric analysis identified five major sub-populations of IELs based on the expression of CD4, CD8, and TcR. These five major sub-populations were further categorized using additional phenotypic criteria.

One of these five sub-populations, comprising CD8 y CD4 q a bTcR q cells, has previously been interpreted to be indicative of contamination with lamina propria andror Peyer's patch lymphocytes Ž . Lefrançois, 1994 . We believe, however, that this interpretation is not correct. B-lymphocytes are a sensitive measure of contamination of IEL populations with lamina propria and Peyer's patch lympho-Ž . cytes Kearsey and Stadnyk, 1996 , and we observed very low numbers of B cells in our IEL preparations Ž . Fangmann et al., 1991b; Lefrançois, 1994 . Essentially all of the cells in each of the five major IEL sub-populations expressed the activation marker CD25, suggesting that the intestinal environment activates IELs irrespective of their intestinal or thymic origin. The presence of CD25 q IELs further suggests that IL-2 may be produced in the intestinal tissue and may in part control the functional activity of IELs. This inference is supported by the detection of abundant IL-2 mRNA in preparations of purified Ž . IELs Kearsey and Stadnyk, 1996 . The variable expression of CD5 we observed in the IEL sub-populations has been previously noted, and it has been suggested that the variability is Ž age-related Fangmann et al., 1991b; Takimoto et al., . 1992 . Our data suggest that, in addition to age, expression of CD5 may be subset-dependent. Depending on subset, the proportion of CD5 q cells Ž . varied from very low to very high Table 3 .

The present studies have also identified and characterized a population of ab y and gdTcR y IELs that express the NKR-P1 marker; such cells are NK Ž . cells Chambers et al., 1989 . This population of cells was almost completely restricted to the CD4 y CD8 y IEL population and are CD2 y . They are unlike peripheral NK cells in the rat, which are q Ž . q Ž CD2 Vaage et al., 1991 and CD8 Woda and . Biron, 1986 . Cells positive for NKR-P1 staining comprised 25-30% of IELs. The majority of the NKR-P1 q NK cells were also RT6 q and CD25 q . In a preliminary report, it has been suggested that peripheral NK cells express low levels of RT6 Ž . Wonigeit et al., 1997 , and recent work in our Ž laboratory has confirmed this report DT, unpub-. lished observations . In contrast, we observed that RT6 is expressed on NK IELs at a very high density that was comparable to that observed on TcR q IELs Ž . Fangmann et al., 1991a,b; Waite et al., 1996 .

In conclusion, we report a new isolation method for rat IELs that is noteworthy for its reproducible high yields. IELs isolated using this method include five major sub-populations, among them significant numbers of gdTcR q and NK cells. The rapidity, efficiency, and product purity that characterize the ( ) method should facilitate functional and developmental studies of IEL sub-populations in the rat. Detailed analysis of IEL sub-populations using this new method may facilitate analyses of the mechanisms of oral tolerance.
